title-group.article-title: Preparation and performance of silver nanoparticle incorporated polyetherethersulfone nanofiltration membranes

contrib-group.aff: Membrane Laboratory, Department of Chemical Engineering, Alagappa College of Technology, Anna University, Chennai, Tamil Nadu, India

author-notes.corresp: D. Mohan, Membrane Laboratory, Department of Chemical Engineering, Alagappa College of Technology, Anna University, Chennai 600025, Tamil Nadu, India. Email: mohantarun@gmail.com

abstract.p: Studies on the preparation of nanofiltration (NF) membranes with silver nanoparticle (Ag-Np) were conducted. The membranes were synthesized with different concentrations of Ag-Np by the phase inversion method, using 1-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP) as the solvent and deionized water as the coagulant. Ag-Np was prepared by the simple chemical reduction method. The formation, structure, morphology and size of Ag-Np were characterized by ultraviolet–visible spectroscopy, x-ray diffractometer (XRD), scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM). Polyetherethersulfone/Ag-Np flat-sheet membranes were prepared by the phase inversion method and investigated in terms of compaction, pure water flux, water content, hydraulic resistance, molecular weight cut-off (MWCO), porosity, hydrophilicity and mechanical properties. The morphology of the membranes was studied by SEM. The elemental composition of the membranes was evaluated by energy dispersive x-ray (EDX). Performance of the membranes was evaluated by mono and divalent metal ion rejection studies. Antibacterial activity studies of the membranes were evaluated by the Muller-Hinton disk diffusion method, against the gram negative (bacterium) of Escherichia coli (E.coli) and the gram positive bacterium of Staphylococcus aureus (S.aureus). The results revealed that the incorporation of Ag-Np increases the performance of the membranes.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
Many of the developing countries are facing severe water scarcity worldwide, due to the rapid growth of population and an advancing economy that has resulted in greater demand for quality drinking water. India has 4% of the world’s water, but it would become a water stressed nation by 2020. Many of the rivers in India are affected by chemical contamination. Due to this, none of the rivers have potable water due to the presence of high concentration of hazardous metals, affecting human health and the environment. In 2030, the global consumption of water would increase to 6900 billion m3, as a result of which the available water will no longer be sufficient to meet the future needs of mankind. 1
–3 There is an urgent need to obtain new technology for obtaining clean water. The discovery of synthetic polymeric membranes is the most significant development in water treatment for producing high-quality drinking water compared with conventional techniques developed during the middle of this century. Membrane technologies are nowadays used for a wide range of industrial separation applications as unit operations for resource recovery, pollution prevention, energy production and environmental monitoring and quality control. The development of novel asymmetric membranes with high efficiency and refinements in membrane technology continue to be the active themes of research. 4
,5 Despite the fact that we live in a period of an advanced technology and innovation, infectious diseases transmitted by contaminated water continue to pose great health challenges worldwide. Pollutants, salts and impurities from drinking water can be effectively removed by nanofiltration (NF) membranes. Nanotechnology for water purification has been identified as a high-priority area since the materials designed at the nanoscale level have relatively a large surface area-to-volume ratio, which is generally not seen in their conventional, bulk counterparts. NF properties are intermediate between those of reverse osmosis (RO) and ultrafiltration (UF). NF with a molecular weight cut-off (MWCO) ranging between 200 and 1000 Da displays separation characteristics between RO and UF membranes. 6 NF is designed to achieve high removal of divalent and multivalent ions and moderate removal of monovalent ions. 5 Composite membranes exhibit both high water permeability and high salt rejection. The fabrication of polymeric membranes with the addition of nanoparticles is gaining attention recently, due to the large surface area-to-volume ratio of nanoparticles that provides a specific functionality to the membrane, which enhances the hydrophilicity, permeability and solute rejection (SR) of the bare membranes. 7–9

In recent years, a variety of nanoparticles have been incorporated to modify polymeric membranes such as silica (SiO2), alumina (Al2O3), zirconia (ZrO2), zinc oxide (ZnO), titania (TiO2), magnesia (MgOH2), palladium (Pd), zerovalent iron (Fe0), gold (Au), silver (Ag) and carbon nanotubes. 10–15 Silver nanoparticle (Ag-Np) has received attention due to its extraordinary antibacterial property at a low concentration to remove microbial contamination. Nowadays, the incorporation of an antibacterial agent into polymeric membranes has been receiving increasing attention. In order to prepare biofouling resistant membranes, incorporation of Ag-Np is an effective way to remove microorganisms in water treatment. Ag-Np have higher specific surface area and a high fraction of surface atoms that lead to a high antimicrobial activity compared with bulk silver metal. The nanoparticles exert their antimicrobial property by interacting with the sulfur-containing proteins present in bacterial cell membrane as well as with phosphorus containing DNA. 12
,14

The separation of heavy metal ions from wastewater can also be achieved using synthetic membranes. Generally, the incorporation of nanoparticles into polymeric membranes is carried out by the coating and deposition of the nanoparticle on the membrane surface. However, blending the nanoparticles into the membrane casting solution can be achieved by a simple operation. Among various high-performance polymers, PEES has been widely used because of its easy film forming properties and resistance to acidic conditions. 16
,17 There is no available literature for the fabrication of PEES/Ag-Np NF membrane for industrial applications.

The current study focuses on fabricating high-efficiency biofouling resistant NF membranes by the incorporation of Ag-Np into the PEES polymer. The Ag-Np was synthesized by the chemical reduction method and was characterized by UV-Visible spectroscopy, XRD, scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM). Membrane performances were evaluated by compaction, pure water flux (PWF), Water content (WC), MWCO, porosity, hydrophilicity and mechanical properties. The morphology of the membranes was evaluated by SEM. The elemental composition was analyzed by energy dispersive x-ray (EDX). Antibacterial activities of the membranes were carried out against E.coli and S. aureus. The performance of the membranes was evaluated by the separation of mono and divalent metal ions.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: All the chemicals and reagents used were of analytical grades. Silver nitrate, tri-sodium citrate and sodium formaldehyde sulfoxylate dihydrate were procured from Merck (I) Ltd (India), to prepare Ag-Np.

Commercial grade PEES with a glass transition temperature of 192°C procured from Sigma-Aldrich (India) were used as such. Analar grade N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP) and analar sodium lauryl sulfate (SLS) were obtained from SRL Chemicals Ltd (India). To remove moisture from the NMP, the solvent was sieved through molecular sieves (type 5 Å) and stored in a dried condition prior to use. Sodium chloride (NaCl) and magnesium sulfate (MgSO4) were purchased from Merck (I) Ltd (India) and used as such.
Microbiology agar from Merck was used for preparing antibacterial plates. Distilled water was used for the UF experiments and for the preparation of the coagulation bath.

sec.title: Synthesis of Ag-Np
sec.p: Ag-Np was synthesized following the procedure reported in literature. 18 An aqueous solution of 0.06 M tri-sodium citrate was added dropwise to an aqueous solution of 0.03 M silver nitrate, at room temperature with continuous stirring. After the complete addition of tri-sodium citrate, stirring was continued for an additional 15 min. Then, 0.03 M aqueous sodium formaldehyde sulfoxylate was added to this solution. The dark grey precipitate formed was washed with methanol and dried.

sec.title: Preparation of NF membranes
sec.p: The NF membranes were prepared by phase inversion method using PEES/Ag-Np. Homogeneous solutions were prepared by dissolving 20 wt% of polymer in the presence and absence of Ag-Np in NMP, under constant mechanical stirring in a round-bottomed flask for 6 h at 80°C. The silver entrapped membranes were prepared by dissolving different amounts of Ag-Np in corresponding volumes of NMP for 3 h by mechanical stirring at 300 rpm at room temperature. The following concentrations of Ag-Np were used: 0.2, 0.4, 0.6, 0.8 and 1 wt%. The homogeneous solution was allowed to stand at room temperature for at least 6 h in an airtight, round-bottomed flask to get rid of air bubbles. The casting environmental conditions, such as relative humidity and temperature, were standardized for the preparation of membranes with better physical properties, such as homogeneity, thickness and smoothness. The relative humidity was maintained at 18%, and the temperature was kept at 25 ± 2°C for all the casting experiments. The homogeneous solution obtained was cast on a glass plate using a doctor’s blade, allowed to evaporate for 30 ± 2 s and immersed in a gelation bath at 10 ± 2°C. The gelation bath contained 2 L of water (nonsolvent), 4 g of SLS and 2 wt% NMP solution. The membranes were subsequently stored in 0.1% formalin solution to prevent microbial growth.

sec.title: Experimental setup
sec.p: The NF permeation experiments were carried out in a cross-flow filtration setup in which four membrane cells were connected in a series. The schematic representation of the NF experimental setup is shown in Figure 1. The effective membrane area available for NF was 19.6 cm2. A centrifugal pump was used to pass the feed solution through the membrane surface. The valve located at the end of the cell was used to pressurize the feed solutions and to control the feed pressure. All the experiments were carried out at a temperature of 30 ± 2°C and at a transmembrane pressure (TMP) of 1718 KPa.

caption.p: The schematic representation of the nanofiltration experimental setup.

sec.title: Characterizations of Ag-Np
sec.p: UV–visible spectra were recorded on a UV 1800 Shimadzu UV spectrophotometer. The surface morphology of the Ag-Np were studied by field-emission SEM (FE-SEM) using a JEOL JSM-7500F microscope operating at 20 kV at a working distance of 8 mm. Powder x-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were measured using Cu-Kα radiation (λλ = 1.5406 Å) on a XPERT PRO. The average size of the crystallite was calculated using the Debye-Scherrer formula and the calculated surface area was estimated with XRD. 19 TEM was done using a Tecnai 10 Philips microscope.

sec.title: Morphological studies
sec.p: The top surface and cross-sectional images of membranes were studied using FE-SEM using a JEOL JSM-7500F microscope operating at 20 kV at a working distance of 8 mm. The membranes were cut into pieces of various sizes and mopped with filter paper. These pieces were dipped into liquid N2 for 20–30 s. The frozen bits of the membranes were broken and kept in a desiccator. These dry samples were gold sputtered for producing electric conductivity and to produce photomicrographs. The SEM analysis was carried out in very high vacuum conditions with an operating voltage of 20 kv depending on the physical nature of the sample. The SEM images were taken at various locations. The elemental composition of the membrane surface was analyzed by the EDX (Hitachi S3400).

sec.title: Hydrophilicity
sec.p: The surface wetting behavior of the membranes was measured by the contact angle (CA) technique to examine the hydrophilic nature of the membranes. The water CA of the membrane surface was measured using a CA meter (HO-IAD CAM 01). Deionized water was used as a probe liquid. For each sample, measurements were taken in six different locations and the average was considered.

sec.p:

sec.title: Mechanical properties
sec.p: The mechanical properties of PEES/Ag-Np dry NF membranes were analyzed according to the ASTM D882 standard with an Instron 3369 analyzer at an elongation rate of 10 mm min−1. Strips of membranes, 1 cm in width and 10 cm in length, were prepared. All the samples were cut to a standard shape in ambient conditions (25°C and relative humidity of 68%) before testing. For each membrane, three samples were evaluated and the average values were reported for accuracy.

sec.title: Molecular weight cut-off
sec.p:
The MWCO of the membranes was determined to study their rejection behavior. The MWCO of a membrane corresponds to the molecular weight of the solute having a SR above 90%. The MWCO of the pure PEES and PEES/Ag-Np membranes were determined using polyethylene glycol (PEG) with different molecular weights. Solutions were prepared individually at a concentration of 500 mg L−1 using deionized water. The NF feed tank was filled with the PEG solution and pressurized at a constant pressure of 1380 kPa throughout the experiments. During NF, the permeate solutions of the corresponding membranes were collected in a graduated tube and analyzed for the solute concentration using a total organic carbon analyzer (Shimadzu, TOC-V CPH). A series of PEGs with different molecular weights such as 200, 400, 600, 700, 1000, 1500, 2000 and 4000 Da were used for the estimation of MWCO and SR studies. sec.p: The salt rejection and salt solution permeate flux of the membranes were studied by filtering MgSO4 and NaCl electrolyte solutions individually, at an operating pressure of 1380 kPa. sec.title: Antibacterial activity studies
sec.p: The antibacterial activity of polymeric membranes E 0.2, E 0.4, E 0.6, E 0.8 and E 1, was determined by the Muller-Hinton disc diffusion method. The Muller-Hinton agar (MHA) medium was used for the antibacterial activity. The MHA medium was used for the preparation of plates (90 mm diameter). The medium was poured on to the sterile petri plates. The agar was allowed to set at ambient temperature. The antibacterial activities of polymeric membrane compounds E 0.2, E 0.4, E 0.6, E 0.8 and E 1 were tested against human pathogenic bacteria. Fresh human pathogenic bacteria cultures of gram-positive bacterium S. aureus (ATCC) and gram-negative bacterium, E. coli (ATCC) were used for the bacterial studies. The bacterial cultures were spread on the surface of the MHA plates with the swab. The MHA plates were allowed to set for the preincubation period of 10 min. The concentrated compounds were placed by a disc.

The inoculated plates were initially incubated for 15 min at room temperature and then they were incubated at 37°C for 24 h. Then, the plates were examined for any zone of growth inhibition. Inhibition zones were recorded as the diameter of growth-free zones including the diameter of the well in millimeter at the end of the incubation period. 6

sec.title: Optical properties of Ag-Np
sec.p: The structural characterization of Ag-Np was mostly studied by UV–visible spectroscopy. The UV–visible absorption spectrum of Ag-Np, shown in Figure 2, reveals the formation of Ag-Np as depicted by the surface plasmon absorption maxima at 400 nm. The results confirmed the formation of Ag-Np by chemical reduction method using a mixture of citrate of sodium as a reducing agent. The broad absorption band is responsible for the vibration of free electrons of metal nanoparticles in resonance with a light wave. The plasmon resonance peak at about 400 nm is the characteristic peak of the nanosilver. 23

sec.title: XRD measurement
sec.p: The structure of the prepared nanoparticles has been investigated by XRD. The XRD pattern of Ag-Np is shown in Figure 3. The results revealed that the powdered Ag-Np exhibits a face-centered cubic crystal structure of silver, showing peaks at 2θ 38.1 (111), 44.3(200), 64.5 (220) and 77.4 (311), which exactly matched with the standard data. 18 From this analysis, a mathematical calculation of the average particle diameter was obtained using the Debye-Scherrer formula. The average particle size obtained from XRD data is 14.92 nm. The surface area from the XRD pattern obtained was about 38.3 m2 g−1.

sec.title: Scanning electron microscopy
sec.p: The morphology of Ag-Np powder is shown in Figure 4. Images were taken at different locations with different magnifications. The SEM analysis shows widely distributed particles of spherical morphology with the usual agglomeration, due to the presence of the surfactants/capping agents. The SEM analysis clearly confirmed that the average size of the spherical particles was 100 nm.

sec.title: Transmission electron microscopy
sec.p: A typical TEM analysis of Ag-Np obtained from the present method is shown in Figure 5. The particles can be seen as dark regions, surrounded by grey regions, where vacuum is present. The particles seemed to be partly transparent. This is inherent to the technique on which TEM is based, where imaging is based on the interaction of the electrons transmitting through the sample. The particles distributed were 70–100 nm in size. The morphology of the particle is spherical with homogeneous distribution, yet some clustering was observed due to the presence of the capping agent. The image clearly shows a periodic line structure mainly visible at the edges of the particle, which is the direct result of the crystal structure of the silver. From these results, the size of the particle is seen to be 70–100 nm, which agrees with the results obtained from the SEM and XRD.

sec.title: Morphology by SEM
sec.p: The qualitative information of the membrane performance was effectively visualized by SEM. It is a powerful tool to investigate the structure of asymmetric polymeric membranes, containing a thin top layer and a porous sublayer. To develop high-performance polymeric membranes, it is essential to design the molecular and morphological structures of the membranes for specific applications. The surface and cross-section of the thin film has a fundamental role in identifying the mechanism of selectivity and permeability. 24 The structure of the asymmetric or anisotropic membrane prepared by a non-solvent-induced phase separation usually contains a relatively thin skin supported on a much thicker sponge-like substructure. During operation, this top skin layer would offer high resistance to the material transport and the lower sponge-type structure would offer less resistance to the material transport, besides providing mechanical strength to the membrane. 25–27 Figures 6 and 7 show the SEM photographs of the top surface and cross-sections of the PEES/Ag-Np NF membranes. These results revealed that the morphology of the membranes was drastically changed by the addition of Ag-Np in the casting solution. Figure 6 shows that the PEES membrane surface remained the same, with the addition of up to 0.8 wt % of Ag-Np. However, further increase in the concentration of Ag-Np at 1 wt% showed clusters or aggregates of Ag-Np in the PEES membrane surface.

caption.p: Membrane surface morphology of PEES/Ag-Np NF membranes.
Membrane cross-sectional morphology of PEES/Ag-Np NF membranes.

sec.p:
Cross-sectional images of the synthesized membranes were also analyzed using SEM. Figure 7 shows that an increase in the concentration of Ag-Np in the solution decreases the macrovoid formation, and this leads to the formation of a more spongy structure due to delayed demixing. This is due to the fact that the transport of a nonsolvent (distilled water) into the polymer solution is much slower than that of the solvent NMP into the water. This phenomenon is related to the superior miscibility of these solvents and water and to the hydrophobic nature of the polymer when water is used as the nonsolvent. From Figure 7, it was seen that the pure PEES membrane showed a finger-like pores in the membrane structure due to an instantaneous demixing favored by thermodynamic instability. This indicates that a high polymer concentration (20 wt%) indeed results in a porous membrane with finger-like pores and macrovoids. 15
,27 Incorporation of different concentration of Ag-Np in the casting solution leads to a slow precipitation rate and results in the formation of the spongy structure.

The silver elemental distributions on the membrane samples were determined using the EDX. The EDX spectrum of the membranes revealed the characteristic peaks assigned to the C, O, S and Ag, as shown in Figure 8. These results revealed that the Ag-Np at higher concentration (E 1) showed a higher entrapment of Ag-Np within the membrane matrix. These results confirmed that the 0.5 wt% of the Ag-Np was highly entrapped by the membrane matrix at a higher concentration (1 wt%).

caption.p: EDX analysis of PEES/Ag-Np NF membranes.

sec.title: Compaction
sec.p:
The membrane transport phenomenon was measured by compaction. When membranes were subjected to high TMPs compared with the operating pressure, it leads to a reduction in the permeability of the membrane due to the reorganization of the polymeric chains. 24 These results exhibit the mechanical deformation of the solid polymeric membranes. The effect of Ag-Np additive in the casting solution at different weight percentages of PEES/Ag-Np on the PWF during compaction is shown in Figure 9. It is observed that in the case of membrane E, the PWF decreased from 145.58 L m−2 h−1 with an increase in the time of compaction, and almost remained constant, that is 81.40 lm−2 h−1, after a definite time interval between 1 to 2 h, indicating the completion of compaction. Thus, an increase in the composition of Ag-Np in the casting solution enhances the hydrophilicity of the membrane, and hence, a higher flux has been observed for membranes with a higher composition of up to 0.6 wt% of Ag-Np (Table 1). Further increase in the concentration of Ag-Np in the casting solution has resulted in an increase in the thickness of the membrane top layer, as confirmed by the SEM analysis. However, the water flux is inversely proportional to the thickness of the membrane, 13
,15 while the sublayer is very porous. A lower water flux is observed as the top layer becomes thicker when observed in case of the membranes E 0.8 and E 1. The comparatively higher flux in membranes with the addition of nanoparticles in the lower concentration range is probably due to the hindrance encouraging a more easy diffusion of solvent molecules from the polymer matrix, resulting in the formation of a membrane with a more porous structure.

sec.title: Permeability and hydrophilicity
sec.p: After the initial compaction at 1718 KPa, all the membranes were analyzed for PWF at a constant TMP of 1380 KPa. The PWFs of all the membranes were measured, subsequent to the initial stabilization period of 10–20 min. The effect of Ag-Np concentration on the PWF of the PEES/Ag-Np membranes is shown in Figure 10. The addition of Ag-Np at 0.6 wt% has shown higher permeability when compared with other membranes. This may be due to the presence of Ag-Np that is associated with the higher affinity of nanoparticles toward water in comparison with the hydrophobic polymers. It also affects the interaction between the solvent and the polymer molecules by the hindrance behavior of the nanoparticles. Further increase in the concentration of Ag-Np decreases the permeability of the membranes, which may be due to the presence of the higher amount of Ag-Np that may be entrapped by the membrane matrix, blocking the pores and reducing the permeability of the membranes. Surface wettability is one of the important membrane properties, which could affect the flux and antifouling ability of the membranes. The CA is often used to describe the surface hydrophilicity. 28 The data showed that the Ag-Np-incorporated PEES polymer showed a lower CA when compared with the E membrane. In general, membrane hydrophilicity is higher, while its CA is smaller. As revealed in Figure 10, it was found that the CA of the PEES/Ag-Np NF membranes decreased significantly with increasing Ag-Np concentration at 0.8 wt% and then increased with further increase in the concentration of Ag-Np.

caption.p: Permeability and hydrophilicity performance of PEES/Ag-Np NF membranes.

sec.title: Hydraulic resistance
sec.p: Membrane hydraulic resistance is an important parameter, which reflects the tolerance of the membranes toward hydraulic pressure. It would be more useful to apply the membrane to a particular environment and to identify the suitability of the membranes for a particular membrane process. Figure 11 shows the hydraulic resistance of the PEES/Ag-Np NF membranes. It was observed that the pure PEES (20 wt%) membrane showed a higher hydraulic resistance of 9.2 lb in−2 or L m−2 h−1 when compared with the other membranes. An increase in the concentration of Ag-Np (0.6 wt%) lowers the hydraulic resistance of the membrane due to the enhancement of the size of pores to a greater extent due to the segmental gap between the polymer chains. Further increase in the Ag-Np in the casting solution may result in the Ag-Np being entrapped by the membrane matrix as observed by the membrane surface analysis by SEM.

caption.p: Hydraulic resistance behavior of PEES/Ag-Np NF membranes.

sec.title: Membrane porosity, MWCO and water content
sec.p: Membrane porosity is a crucial membrane property that can be manipulated by systematically varying membrane preparation parameters. Table 2 illustrates the effect of Ag-Np concentration on the membrane porosity, water content and MWCO of PEES/Ag-Np NF membranes. The addition of Ag-Np (0.6 wt%) increases the membrane porosity, MWCO and water content. Further increase in the Ag-Np concentration leads to a lower porosity and water content. This may be due to the fact that the permeation performance is dominated by the structure of the skin layer. The membrane porosity is related to the pore formation during the process of membrane formation by immersion precipitation, 25 in which delayed demixing occurred at high concentrations of Ag-Np. The results showed that the addition of Ag-Np up to 0.6 wt% increases the water content of the membranes. This is due to the leachability behavior of the Ag-Np at its lower concentration. However, beyond 0.6 wt%, the water content of all the membranes decreased due to the entrapment of Ag-Np on the membrane matrix, which does not allow the Ag-Np to be leached out during gelation and this in turn reduces the pore size of the membranes at higher concentration. A higher concentration of Ag-Np increases the thickness of skin layer and the connectivity of the pores between the sublayer and the bottom layer. This may be because of the slow diffusion of the NMP and water during the phase inversion process of membrane preparation, resulting in a much denser skin layer and a spongy sublayer. From the observed results, it was confirmed that increasing the concentration of Ag-Np (E 0.8 and E 1) decreases the water content, porosity and MWCO of the membranes. The MWCO of the membrane is determined by identifying an inert molecule of the lowest molecular weight, which has an SR of 80–90% in steady state NF experiments.

caption.p: Effect of Ag-Np on porosity, MWCO and water content of PEES/Ag-Np membranes.

sec.title: Mechanical properties
sec.p: The mechanical properties of the NF membranes are of particular interest, as they are highly related to the stress encountered by the membrane during operation. The mechanical properties of the PEES/Ag-Np NF membranes are shown in Table 3. The results indicate that the addition of Ag-Np (0.6 wt%) decreased the tensile strength of the PEES membranes. Further increase in the Ag-Np increases the tensile strength. However, the elongation at break of the PEES membrane increased considerably up to 1 wt% blend composition. The entrapped Ag-Np blocks the growing crack, as a result of which the crack path is deviated by absorbing more energy, which obviously enhanced the tensile strength with a higher percentage (0.8 and 1 wt%) of Ag-Np. Generally, higher tensile strength and longer elongation are associated with the dense skin and tight interior structure of the membranes. These studies indicate that the decrease in the tensile strength leads to an increase in the water content and porosity of the membranes. This behavior can be related to the enhanced macrovoid formation and a higher specific area of nanoparticles favoring water sorption inside the membranes.

caption.p: Mechanical properties of PEES/Ag-Np NF membranes.

sec.title: Membrane performance and permeation of mono and divalent metal ions
sec.p: One of the most important features of NF membranes is their ability to separate ions from water. The NF is designed to achieve high removal of divalent and multivalent ions and moderate removal of monovalent ions. The permeation test was conducted using a cross-flow filtration cell. Circular membrane discs were cut and mounted on a stainless steel, cylindrical membrane test cell on a porous support and tightened by a rubber oring. The effective permeation area of each membrane was about 19.6 cm2. Prior to testing, the PWF was measured to ensure that the membranes used were stable. The feed pressure was set at about 1380 KPa, while the permeate side was opened to the atmosphere. Experiments were carried out at an ambient temperature of 27°C. The flux rate and SR were measured using a 1000 mg L−1 of NaCl and MgSO4 feed solution. The ion concentrations of the feed and permeate were measured using a conductivity meter, model LF 330.

In NF, the charge of the membrane has a significant effect on the membrane performance, since the charge affects the electrostatic interaction between the charged molecules and the membrane surface. The charge of the membrane depends on the operational pH of the system, because the membrane functional groups protonate and deprotonate over the pH under study. 27 The salt rejection properties of PEES/Ag-Np were studied by filtering salt solutions of MgSO4 and NaCl at pH 6.5. From the rejection values (Table 4), it was clear that the rejection increased as the concentration of Ag-Np increased, due to the smaller size of the pores. The pure PEES membranes in the absence of Ag-Np exhibited 74.3% rejection for MgSO4 and 40.8% for NaCl, which was higher than that observed in the presence of Ag-Np (0.6 wt%). Thus, the percentage rejection of electrolyte solutions were in the order MgSO4 > NaCl. This is due to the presence of positive charge on the membranes that preferably rejects cations of higher valance, which results in higher rejection of magnesium than sodium. Furthermore, an increase in the concentration of Ag-Np results in an increase in the rejection of the ions due to the presence of smaller pore size.

caption.p: Metal ion rejection and permeation studies of PEES/Ag-Np NF membranes.

sec.p: The permeate flux of the MgSO4 and NaCl in the presence and absence of Ag-Np–incorporated PEES membranes is shown in Table 4. The results show that the pure PEES membrane in the absence of Ag-Np showed 119.2 L m−2 h−1 for MgSO4. The other electrolyte, NaCl, solution had higher flux values because of larger membrane pore size. The reduction in the permeate flux is proportional to the chloride ion retention. Large negative charges in the membrane structure facilitate chloride ion permeation through the membrane, which, as a consequence, minimized the membrane polarization and caused an increase in the permeate flux. Additionally, the sulfate ions improved this process because of the Donnan effect appearing.

sec.title: Antibacterial activity of the PEES/Ag-Np NF membranes
sec.p: To examine the antibacterial activity of the PEES membranes in the presence of Ag-Np by the Muller-Hinton disk diffusion method, 29–32 human pathogenic bacteria such as gram-positive bacterium, S. aureus, and gram-negative bacterium, E. coli, were chosen. It is found that all the membranes with Ag-Np exhibit antibacterial activity by the appearance of an inhibition zone, except the pure PEES membrane (E). The bacterial activities of the PEES/Ag-Np NF membranes are shown in Figures 12 and 13. These results revealed that, when higher concentrations of Ag-Np were incorporated in the PEES membranes, they showed the highest percentage of inhibition against S. aureus and E. coli. Table 5 shows the zone of inhibition and the percentage zone of inhibition of the PEES/Ag-Np NF membranes. Compared with all the six membranes, the compound E 1 showed good antibacterial activity against E. coli at 23.33% and S. aureus at 22.22% and E 0.8 showed activity against E. coli at 21.11% and S. aureus at 18.88% followed by E 0.6 that showed activity against E. coli at 18.88% and S. aureus at 17.77%; other membranes showed moderate activity; the pure PEES membrane has no activity toward E. coli and S. aureus. It can be concluded, that at higher concentrations of Ag-Np, successful biofouling resistant membranes were produced. High antibacterial activity with very low loading and improved distribution of the Ag-Np in the polymer matrix are the essential properties to develop a biofouling resistant membrane.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: High-performance NF membranes were prepared by the phase inversion method. Ag-Np was synthesized by the water-based chemical reduction method. The formation of Ag-Np was confirmed by UV–visible spectroscopy and the indication of a peak at 400 nm. The TEM analysis revealed a particle size of 70–100 nm. The concentration of nanoparticles is a crucial factor in order to achieve the expected improvement in Ag-Np entrapped membranes compared with the PEES membrane. The EDX results confirmed that at higher concentration of 1 wt%, the Ag-Np was entrapped on the membrane matrix. The results revealed 0.5 wt% of the Ag-Np entrapped on the membrane matrix. The morphology of the membranes showed that the incorporation of Ag-Np greatly affected the permeability of the membrane. The results from the study showed that the PEES/Ag-Np NF membrane showed better performance at 0.6 wt% of Ag-Np in the PEES membranes. It was observed that the Ag-Np membrane showed a lower flux decline and a better permeability compared with the pure polymeric membrane due to a higher hydrophilicity of the PEES/Ag-Np NF membranes. Overall, 79% of the magnesium ions were effectively removed with high flux by the PEES/Ag-Np NF membranes. Thus, the present study reveals that the PEES/Ag-Np NF membranes are promising candidates for the efficient removal of both mono and divalent heavy metal ions from industrial waste water with increased flux. The antibacterial PEES/Ag-Np membranes were successfully fabricated. From the results, it is seen that the PEES/Ag-Np membrane with 1 wt% of Ag-Np showed high activity in the antibacterial test against E. coli and S. aureus. Therefore, it can be concluded that the presence of Ag-Np at higher concentration in the PEES/Ag-Np had significantly improved the membrane performance in antibacterial activity.
